DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China is purchasing US agricultural goods now and that any issues in phase 2 talks with China are in many ways a lot easier than the issues faced in phase 1. Furthermore, Trump had also stated that a trade deal with China is coming along great and reiterated his hope to have phase 1 of the deal signed at APEC summit. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer reiterated the target is to have the phase one trade deal with China by the time of the APEC summit in mid-November but added that issues still remain. Furthermore, Lighthizer said deputy level call with Chinese trade team happened this morning and that the primary level phone conversation will happen with China’s Vice Premier Liu He on Friday. (Newswires/Fox)

NEC Director Kudlow said there is a chance that the US December tariffs on China could be taken off if phase 1 talks go well. (Newswires)

China’s Vice Premier Liu He and EU Commissioner Katainen are to meet soon for high level talks about bilateral investment treaty and geographical indications, according to reports citing sources. (Handelsblatt)

China is seeking USD 2.4bln in retaliatory sanctions against the US for non-compliance with WTO ruling in tariffs case dating to Obama era, according to a document. (Newswires)

US-China Business Council executive said US companies are preparing for tensions with China to last beyond current trade discussions and have begun diversifying supply-chain investments away from China. (WSJ)

Indian Trade Minister said they have almost resolved broad contours of a trade deal with US and that a relationship between the two countries may go to a bilateral agreement beyond deal that was going to be announced. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK House Speaker Bercow blocked a Meaningful Vote on UK PM Johnson’s Brexit deal as expected, while he added that it is hard to see a significant change of circumstance that would warrant a reconsideration on the next sitting and that the substance is the same as that of Saturday. (Newswires)

UK government published the Withdrawal Agreement Bill on Monday night which will see its first vote at 1900BST on Tuesday, while the government is said to be aiming to wrap up Brexit legislation by Thursday. (BBC/CNN)

UK Minister Gove said there has been no formal response from the EU regarding UK PM Johnson's letters, while Gove added he must now take the correct steps to deal with the increased chance of a No-Deal Brexit. (Newswires)

German Foreign Minister said a short technical Brexit extension would not be ruled out. (Newswires)

Germany's Bundesbank said the German Economy may have shrunk in Q3 and sees the risk of a slowdown in German exports affecting the domestic economy as well. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said he thinks it is a foregone conclusion that the House will vote to impeach him. (Sky News) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Coty (COTY) higher after reports it is mulling the sale of its hair and nail products, which could fetch between USD 8-9bln. HP Enterprises (HPE) higher after a double upgrade to buy from underperform at Bank of America. Haliburton (HAL) earnings missed on revenues, while EPS was in line with expectations, which saw the energy company trade lower in the pre-market, however CEO confirming expectations for a high single digit international growth for all of 2019, helped it go positive. Boeing (BA) was red following a PT cut at Credit Suisse and UBS, with the former noting that the latest discoveries increase the risk profile for investors, and the bank can no longer defend the industrial giant’s shares. However, on a positive note Europe's EASA expects to clear Boeing’s 737 MAX for service in January at the earliest as long as things go well, noting the timing between FAA and EASA over 737 MAX return to service is likely to be weeks and not months. Cardinal Health (CAH), McKesson (MCK), and AmerisourceBergen (ABC) traded lower after reaching an agreement with two Ohio counties related to the opioid crisis, but failed to reach a broad agreement with thousands of other authorities; however, Teva (TEVA) traded higher as it reportedly only has to pay USD 20mln, lower than the distributors’ USD 215mln. During trading hours, some of the initial downside in the distributors was reversed, as Teva reached a settlement on the track 1 opioid case, which saw Teva rise ~15% at its highs before paring back slightly, distributors MCK, CAH & ABC remained in the red, but not as heavily as the morning. Colorado has reportedly agreed to end its involvement in a multi-state lawsuit seeking to block the merger of Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) in exchange for assurances that Dish Network’s new wireless phone service and some 2,000 jobs will be headquartered in the Centennial State. Fox (FOXA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) announce a comprehensive distribution agreement which includes the long-term renewal of their distribution agreement for Fox’s full portfolio of news, entertainment and sports networks. S&P 500 0.7% at 3007, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7940, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26826.

Yields were 4-5bps higher across the Treasury curve, and at settlement, major curve spreads were mixed. The downside was said to be a result of continued positive noises from US/China trade talks, while Brexit is moving in a direction that removes any cliff-edge exit, helping to mitigate a key global risk. This week, the US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Tue), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Wed), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Thu); Analysts at UBS note that there are around USD 84bln of cash flows at the end-month settlement (excluding SOMA holdings), including around USD 75bln of redemptions and around USD 9bln of coupons. US T-note (Z9) settled 13 ticks lower at 129-20.

US MARKET WRAP 21st October 2019: Equities drift higher in quiet trade; positive US/China commentary cited
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, USD flat, crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Positive US/China trade chatter; No Brexit meaningful vote on Monday.
  • COMING-UP: Brexit votes; Canada election results; Canada retail sales, US existing home sales; US Richmond Fed manufacturing; NZ trade.

* MARKET WRAP: With no major US data, speakers, or even A-list earnings on the slate, there was a quiet feel to trade on Monday. Much of the focus was on US/China remarks (generally have leaned positive) and Brexit. Trading ranges were generally thin; Treasury yields are higher, the USD is a touch weaker, equities are drifting higher, while crude is lower.

* US CHINA: Over the weekend China Vice President Liu He made positive remarks on trade, noting substantial progress has been made between the US and China, which lays a foundation for the signing of a phased agreement. Liu’s remarks were followed by constructive but cautious remarks by US Commerce Secretary Ross, who noted that there are still outstanding issues in the phase one talks, as well as NEC director Kudlow, who said it was possible that the US might not implement tariffs on Chinese imports that are due to become effective in December, allowing ES futures to modestly move higher to a session high above 3,000. The two sides are to remain in contact ahead of the APEC summit in November, and US President Trump again raised the possibility that a deal might be signed on the sidelines of that summit. Trump also said that the trade deal is coming along great, and that China was now purchasing US agricultural goods. USTR Lighthizer’s remarks were generally toeing the line.

* BREXIT: UK House Speaker Bercow chose not to allow another meaningful vote on UK PM Johnson’s Brexit deal, but said that it is legitimate for the government to introduce its EU Withdrawal Bill (WAB) for a second reading (the government are set to unveil the Bill this evening, ahead of a vote at 1900 BST on Tuesday). The Bill likely be subject to amendments (on remaining in the customs union, putting the deal to the electorate, and possibly even an amendment that seeks to mimic the impact of the so-called Letwin bill, by ruling out a no deal Brexit at end of the transition period), which complicates its passage. Lawmakers will also on Tuesday vote to approve the expedited timeline to get the Bill through parliament, with many Remainers suggesting that the timeline is too narrow to consider such important legislation, an argument that the government has countered by pointing to the three years of debates that have already taken place on these issues. From the EU perspective, reports suggest it is waiting for clarity on how the legislative agenda in parliament plays out before responding to the UK’s request for an A50 extension. Although most EU leaders have expressed a willingness to provide the UK with an extension if needed, so long as it is accompanied by a UK general election or second referendum, French President Macron appears to prefer offering only a short Brexit extension, in order to exert pressure on UK MPs to accept UK PM Johnson’s deal.

* ECB: Ahead of its policy meeting on Thursday -- the last of current President Mario Draghi, before ex-IMF chief Lagarde takes the reins at the November meeting -- ECB officials speaking at the IMF meetings over the past weekend hinted that there was little more to come by way of further monetary policy, at least not in the immediate future, despite anticipated downgrades to its economic projections at the December meeting. On a similar theme, the incoming EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Gentiloni penned an op-ed in Italian press arguing that EU budget rules must be reviewed and updated with the aim of having more public spending, especially from governments with fiscal space. The Bundesbank monthly report noted German’s economic output could have fallen slightly again in Q319, due to a weakening of the country’s export-oriented industry. The German central bank said leading indicators show few signs of a sustained recovery in exports and stabilisation in the industrial sector, adding there is a greater risk the downward trend would seep through to more domestically orientated industries. Despite the worries, Bundesbank did note that a clear, broad based recession is not yet apparent, citing retail figures showing consumer confidence was undiminished and the labour market continued to improve, therefore, resulting in favourable income prospects for the consumer.

* RBA: Deputy Governor Debelle's remarks largely echoed the tone of the recent minutes, and he stated that strong house price growth was not a financial stability risk, so long as it is not accompanied by a material expansion in borrowing. Debelle said that even with 75bps of easing, credit growth was still likely to remain low even as prices picked up, since households may be more conservative in their willingness to borrow given low income growth, and lenders are applying tighter standards than in the past.

* CANADA ELECTIONS PRIMER: The election is expected to deliver an inconclusive result, raising the possibility of a minority government. PM Trudeau's Liberal Party is pretty much running neck-and-neck with the Conservatives, with both polling a little over 30%. It makes the role of smaller political parties more significant; the consensus view seems to suggest that the New Democrats (NDP, who are more likely to side with Liberal party) and Bloc Quebecois party (who are more likely to side with the Conservatives) could ultimately be the kingmakers. The implied outcome from polls generally leans towards the Conservatives winning more votes, but not enough for a majority. ING explains that the main policy differences between the two leading political parties are around the climate and the energy sector: the Liberals aim to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, front-loading them by improving the targets set for 2030, but are still looking to complete the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion, which would expand capacity for carrying oil from Alberta to British Columbia’s coast to 890k BPD from the current 300k BPD. On fiscal policy, the Liberals plan to cut small business tax and middle-class taxes, but would levy a 1.0% surcharge for non-residential property buyers, and give first-time buyers 10% off the price of their first home. If the Liberals require support from the NDP, there are risks that it could support higher corporation tax rates, and even a possible wealth tax. Meanwhile, the opposition Conservatives have pledged to eliminate the carbon tax, will also complete the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion, and seek other investment in energy transportation. The Conservatives have also pledged to cut taxes for middle-income households deeper than the Liberals; ING believes that markets would prefer the Conservative policy agenda, which may be perceived as potentially more likely to offset the increasing concerns about the global economic outlook.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.7% at 3007, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7940, Dow Jones  0.2% at 26826; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  0.5%, Consumer Staples  0.3%, Energy  1.9%, Financials  1.4%, Health Care  -0.1%, Industrials  0.6%, Information Technology  1.1%, Materials  -0.3%, Telecommunication Services  0.4%, Utilities  0.4%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Coty (COTY) higher after reports it is mulling the sale of its hair and nail products, which could fetch between USD 8-9bln. HP Enterprises (HPE) higher after a double upgrade to buy from underperform at Bank of America. Haliburton (HAL) earnings missed on revenues, while EPS was in line with expectations, which saw the energy company trade lower in the pre-market, however CEO confirming expectations for a high single digit international growth for all of 2019, helped it go positive. Boeing (BA) was red following a PT cut at Credit Suisse and UBS, with the former noting that the latest discoveries increase the risk profile for investors, and the bank can no longer defend the industrial giant’s shares. However, on a positive note Europe's EASA expects to clear Boeing’s 737 MAX for service in January at the earliest as long as things go well, noting the timing between FAA and EASA over 737 MAX return to service is likely to be weeks and not months. Cardinal Health (CAH), McKesson (MCK), and AmerisourceBergen (ABC) traded lower after reaching an agreement with two Ohio counties related to the opioid crisis, but failed to reach a broad agreement with thousands of other authorities; however, Teva (TEVA) traded higher as it reportedly only has to pay USD 20mln, lower than the distributors’ USD 215mln. During trading hours, some of the initial downside in the distributors was reversed, as Teva reached a settlement on the track 1 opioid case, which saw Teva rise ~15% at its highs before paring back slightly, distributors MCK, CAH & ABC remained in the red, but not as heavily as the morning. Colorado has reportedly agreed to end its involvement in a multi-state lawsuit seeking to block the merger of Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) in exchange for assurances that Dish Network’s new wireless phone service and some 2,000 jobs will be headquartered in the Centennial State. Fox (FOXA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) announce a comprehensive distribution agreement which includes the long-term renewal of their distribution agreement for Fox’s full portfolio of news, entertainment and sports networks.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.36 LOWER AT USD 53.51; BRENT (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.46 LOWER AT USD 58.96: The oil complex traded lower to start the week. On the demand side, analysts at Citi noted that the downside in prices today was a continuation of concerns on slowing global economic growth and US China trade tensions, however, it noted that US equities were trading higher on positive comments from China Vice Premier Liu He over the weekend – the lack of consistency suggests that the oil market could swing higher again if traders were too convert to the equity investors view. On the supply side, the North Sea Buzzard oil field (which has been shut) may possibly reopen on Friday or Saturday, sources said. This week, analysts expect inventory reports to show crude stocks building by 1.7mln bbls, distillates -2.7mln bbls and gasoline -2.3mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) SETTLED 13 TICKS LOWER AT 129-20. Yields were 4-5bps higher across the Treasury curve, and at settlement, major curve spreads were mixed. The downside was said to be a result of continued positive noises from US/China trade talks, while Brexit is moving in a direction that removes any cliff-edge exit, helping to mitigate a key global risk. This week, the US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Tue), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Wed), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Thu); Analysts at UBS note that there are around USD 84bln of cash flows at the end-month settlement (excluding SOMA holdings), including around USD 75bln of redemptions and around USD 9bln of coupons.

* 2-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Tue), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Wed), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Thu); Analysts at UBS note that there are around USD 84bln of cash flows at the end-month settlement (excluding SOMA holdings), including around USD 75bln of redemptions and around USD 9bln of coupons. The latest Treasury selling builds a solid concession for all three of this week's auctions, analysts at BMO argue, noting that while yields are still some way off the top of recent ranges, the back-up in bullish extremes will likely prevent any significant supply hiccups; but BMO warns that next week's FOMC (on 31st October) could result in some bidder hesitation. "Any Fed-related step-back will not be a function of scepticism of another 25bps cut, but rather that Powell may begin to lay the groundwork for a shift back to pause," the bank argues. "To be fair, the odds of a December cut are currently around 25% (assuming a 25bps cut in October) so any down-trade following a hawkish policy adjustment would likely be limited." BMO argues that it still thinks that the front-end holds plenty of appeal versus OIS, as well as longer-dated Treasuries, and accordingly, the auction's performance may be a function of intraday price action going into the supply. BMO looks for decent performance at this week's auction, and says this is particularly in the context of the Fed’s reserve management purchases in the bill market, and BMO believes that structural demand from the central bank will offer a tailwind to bills versus OIS, and also a degree of outperformance in short coupons as well. "The three rounds of bill buying on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday will each be to the tune of USD 7.5bln in maturities one-year and in, and we soon expect these operations as well as the MBS reinvestments will fade into the background, if for no other reason than the first pass which took place last week saw USD 33bln offered from primary dealers to meet the Fed's USD 7.5bln in demand, which is a testament to the depth and liquidity of the very front-end of the Treasury market."

* FX WRAP: The GBP struggled to sustain gains above 1.30 as further delays are put into the Brexit process; the GBP and EUR were trading up in early trade, with traders reasoning that no deal risks have now fallen substantially; this helped put some pressure on the buck, which was also said to have been pressured by a stronger yuan fixing than was implied by models; the greenback did, however, recoup most of the losses to trade flat heading into APAC trade. Much of the EMFX complex took advantage of the buck’s initial weakness, though not the BRL nor MXN, with LatAm FX being hit by intensifying protests in Chile (Chile the second nation to declare a state of emergency lately, following Ecuador; there are concerns Argentina might be next); BRL will also be paying attention to the final Senate vote on pension reform set to take place on Tuesday. The CAD, meanwhile, is trading firmer against the buck ahead of election results, due aftermarket; polls are currently too close to call, analysts said. Although trade was thin, there were no negative tape bombs, allowing the likes of AUD and NZD to hold on to gains, while XAU fell. 

* CNY: Overnight, the USDCNY came in lower than model projections, likely on the back of constructive comments on trade talks made by China Vice Premier Liu He on the weekend; additionally, some had expected the PBOC to cut its Loan Prime Rate, but left both the 1-year and the 5-year unchanged at 4.2% and 4.85% respectively. ING said that the question is now whether the central bank believes it is unnecessary to reduce rates now, given better than expected September data, or whether it wants to keep the interest rate cut 'bullet' for the future, in case trade tensions escalate further.

* BRL: Desks suggest that Petrobras' upcoming auction of drilling rights could provide support to the real (depending on the dates of settlement, of course - some have suggested it could come in December) given the oil names will be bidding over USD 20bln for the aforementioned rights. The auction would help to offset some of the USD 32bln of outflows Brazil has so far over the last 12 months.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Scandi Crowns and Antipodean Dollars outperform
content:
NOK/SEK/NZD/AUD

The Norwegian and Swedish Krona are back in the ascendency, or rather rebounding further from recent lows in what appears to be a technical correction ahead of this Thursday’s Scandi Central Bank meetings when the Riksbank could reaffirm guidance for another 25 bp rise in the key repo rate late this year or in early 2020. However, a broad upturn in risk appetite is also helping the Nok and Sek remain on the recovery path vs a toppy Eur with the respective crosses down through 10.1550 and 10.7200 respectively at one stage, former largely shrugging off soft oil prices at the same time. Meanwhile, the Kiwi and Aussie consolidated/cemented gains around the 0.6400 handle and just shy of 0.6900, with the latter poised to test a key resistance area from 0.6895-0.6909 on any further Greenback weakness given more positive US-China trade noises (NEC’s Kudlow stating that mid-December tariffs could be lifted if Phase 1 talks proceed well). On that note, the DXY is hovering just above support and the 97.000 mark within a 97.393-144 range, with Usd/CNH easing towards 7.0600 vs a 7.0680 Usd/CNY midpoint fix overnight.

GBP/CAD

The Pound and Loonie are both off best levels vs the Buck awaiting the next Brexit developments and Canadian election results, but not before Cable printed fresh multi-month highs above 1.3000 when stops were triggered and Usd/Cad ducked under support just over 1.3100 to test the water below. Sterling is now digesting HoC Speaker Bercow’s decision to reject the Government’s motion to re-present the WAB on both counts of substance and circumstance after judging that PM Johnson sending a letter of request to the EU does not represent a persuasive argument for a change in the latter. However, Cable remains relatively bid around 1.2980 and Eur/Gbp is holding below 0.8600, albeit not quite as low as last Thursday’s 0.8575 base, while Usd/Cad remains very close to 1.3100 awaiting the first exit polls that are expected to emerge from around 7-8 pm local time.

JPY/EUR/CHF

All softer vs the US Dollar against the backdrop of improved risk sentiment, as Usd/Jpy continues to straddle 108.50, Eur/Usd pivots 1.1150 and Usd/Chf spans 0.9850. Note, the Yen failed to seriously test the 10 DMA at 108.26 or decent option expiries between 108.30-45 (1.4 bn) at NY cut-off time, but the Euro was very close to 1 bn from 1.1150-60.

EM 

The Lira and Real are on the backfoot amidst ongoing attention and concern about Turkey’s military offensive in Syria as the Finance Minister accuses those countries resorting to or threatening sanctions as blackmailing the nation, while the Brl is feeling the heat from unrest in Chile. Usd/Try has been back over 5.8500 and Usd/Brl climbed above 4.1450 before fading.

BREXIT ANALYSIS: Can Johnson get his deal ratified by the 31st October?
content:
* THE LATEST: Parliament’s vote on the government’s recently negotiated Brexit deal was postponed on Saturday, after lawmakers voted (322-306) in favour of passing the Letwin amendment, which withholds approval of the Brexit deal until legislation to ratify it is passed and forces UK PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension to January 31st under the Benn Act. UK PM Johnson sent a letter to the EU requesting a Brexit extension, however, he did not sign the letter and sent 2 other letters alongside it, in which he stated that the extension request was from Parliament and urged the EU not to grant the extension. The EU has not yet responded to the request and, as many desks have noted, may prefer to play the waiting game to see how things unfold in Westminster.

* MEANINGFUL VOTE 2.0: This morning, the government announced its intentions to have another crack at the ‘meaningful vote’ that should have taken place on Saturday. Here, the hope would be that if the government can demonstrate it has a majority for its deal, it would give momentum to the passage of the withdrawal agreement bill later in the week. The Financial Times reported that there are now 11 Labour MPs on-board with the PM’s deal, which, when combined with the 28 ‘Spartans’ and ex-Conservative independents, means there narrowly could be enough support. However, it is up to UK House Speaker Bercow as to whether or not such a vote goes ahead. Parliamentary rules say the same motion cannot be voted on twice in a parliamentary session, so if he says no, PM Johnson will have to introduce the full WAB for second reading. Expectations are that he will not allow another meaningful vote to occur.

* AMENDMENTS: A second reading of the government’s WAB is effectively a new 'meaningful vote', in which MPs will be asked if they broadly support the bill or not. Although the numbers look to be in the PM's favour, amendments, such as one to keep the UK in the Customs Union, could derail process; the last time a Custom’s Union was voted on - as part of the 'indicative votes' back in the Spring - the idea was narrowly defeated, with 273 MPs voting in favour and 276 against. ING flag the risk that things could be a little different now; last time, 89 lawmakers abstained, but some may be more minded to vote 'for' a customs union this time as they may see this amendment as their best chance of derailing the government's efforts to get its deal ratified. If the customs union amendment passes, the assumption is that the bill would lose the support of the 28 Conservative Spartans, potentially destroying the fragile majority for the prime minister's deal. At the moment, a vote on the second reading of government deal is scheduled for 19:00 BST on Tuesday.

* PROGRAMME MOTION: If the second reading of the bill passes parliament, then the government will need to indicate how it intends to get it through parliament before 31 October. By historical standards, 10 days is ‘ambitious’ timeframe to get a bill approved by lawmakers, notes ING. Lawmakers will need to approve this timeline. ING asks, given that this is a matter of significant importance, will MPs be comfortable with the legislation going through so quickly and with minimal scrutiny? This could be a challenge for the government, and failure to get this motion approved will basically rule out leaving the EU on 31 October, the bank argues.

* WHAT ELSE TO WATCH THIS WEEK: Separately, UBS flag the importance of the EU27’s response to the UK’s A50 extension request. UBS suspect that EU will not respond until there is a clear message from the House of Commons, which they think would help UK PM Johnson insistence of Oct. 31 as the final date for the deal to be passed. Finally, Scotland's Court of Session will examine whether the extension request was in line with the law, given that PM Johnson sent two letters alongside the extension request, which expressed that he didn't actually want an extension. UBS say this is a “side show” and will not drive markets, concluding that the key point is that the request is sent, and whether or not the PM signed the letter isn't of market relevance.

* BREXIT BY 31 OCTOBER? Goldman think there is a strong probability that the UK can leave the EU with a deal by the end of the month, assigning a subjective 70% to the outcome. “In our view, the incentives of the Johnson government and the incentives of EU-27 leaders are aligned in aiming to secure an orderly Brexit as soon as possible” states the bank, adding that “from this perspective, the greater the ambiguity surrounding the duration and terms of any Article 50 extension — and the longer that decision is deferred — the greater the pressure on MPs in the House of Commons to come to a firm decision on the merits of the new Withdrawal Agreement.” However, ING flag the possibility that, if an undesirable amendment passes on its second reading of the WAB, such as on a customs union, the government could decide to pull the plug on the whole thing and take the fight to a general election. If the government goes with the latter option, posits ING, then there may well be a vote at some point this week on whether to trigger a general election, meaning the UK could feasibly go to the polls in late November or early December. This would require an extension from the EU, which they have already indicated they would grant.

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European bourses are modestly firmer, FTSE lags amid a firmer pound, SAP shares rose after earnings and announcing a deal with Microsoft
  • UK Parliament vote on the Brexit deal was postponed on Saturday after lawmakers voted (322-306) in favour of passing the Letwin amendment
  • In FX, GBP/USD briefly topped 1.3000, DXY fell further towards 97.00, risk currencies outperform
  • Looking ahead highlights include BoE’s Haldane, Fed’s Bowman, ECB VP de Guindos, Canadian Elections

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with a cautious tone following last Friday’s lacklustre close on Wall St and amid continued Brexit uncertainty. ASX 200 (Unch) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were mixed with Australia dragged by underperformance in the tech sector. However, resilience in the property and mining sectors has limited the losses in Sydney, while Tokyo sentiment was kept afloat by mild JPY weakness as a larger than expected contraction in exports ata added to the pressure for the BoJ to act. Hang Seng (Unch) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) conformed to the indecision after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations but refrained from anticipated cuts to its Loan Prime Rates, with Hong Kong also mildly underpinned after China revised rules to permit mainland investors to trade Hong Kong-listed dual class shares through the Stock Connect. Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower in which prices retested prior support around the 154.00 level and with demand subdued as Japanese stocks remained afloat, although downside was stemmed amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.16tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0680 vs. Exp. 7.0681 (Prev. 7.0690)

PBoC 1yr Loan Prime Rate 4.20% vs. Exp. 4.15% (Prev. 4.20%). (Newswires) PBoC 5yr Loan Prime Rate 4.85% vs. Exp. 4.83% (Prev. 4.85%)

Chinese House Prices (Sep) Y/Y 8.4% (Prev. 8.8%). (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY)(Sep) -123.0B vs. Exp. 54.0B (Prev. -143.5B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Sep) Y/Y -5.2% vs. Exp. -4.0% (Prev. -8.2%) Japanese Imports (Sep) Y/Y -1.5% vs. Exp. -2.8% (Prev. -11.9%)

 

US

China is seeking USD 2.4bln in retaliatory sanctions against the US for non-compliance with WTO ruling in tariffs case dating to Obama era, according to document. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s allies are reportedly compiling a list of potential candidates to replace Acting White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Parliament vote on the Brexit deal was postponed on Saturday after lawmakers voted (322-306) in favour of passing the Letwin amendment which withholds approval of the Brexit deal until legislation to ratify it is passed and which effectively forced PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension to January 31st under the Benn Act. Following this, PM Johnson stated that the legislation will be tabled in the upcoming week and sent a letter to the EU requesting a Brexit extension which he did not sign, while he sent 2 other letters where he stated that the extension request was from Parliament and urged the EU not to grant the extension. (Newswires) UK PM Johnson could be held in contempt by Scottish Court for urging EU leaders to ignore a letter asking for an extension to Brexit. Scotland's most senior judge, Carloway, alongside two other judges will hear the allegations today. (Guardian) UK de facto Deputy Gove has triggered official contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit in an attempt to pressure MPs into backing PM Johnson's Brexit deal. (Guardian) Elsewhere, the UK Government are reportedly drawing up plans for an election as soon as November 28th. (Telegraph)

UK Government spokesperson says talks with the DUP are ongoing; meaningful vote will go ahead if allowed by House Speaker Bercow and no amendments are selected. (Newswires)

UK Foreign Secretary Raab suggested that the government has the numbers to pass the deal in Commons and is confident the UK will leave on October 31st. Cabinet Minister Gove also stated that the UK will still leave on October 31st and that Parliament cannot change the government’s policy or determination, while there were separate comments from MPs Amber Rudd and Sir Oliver Letwin that suggested they will back PM Johnson’s Brexit deal. (Newswires)

Daily Telegraph’s Political Correspondent Yorke tweeted that a senior DUP figure said the party could back a customs union amendment to the WAB in order to ensure whole of the UK leaves EU under the same customs arrangements and that the party will discuss issue over next 24-48 hours, while he added that another DUP figure said they’ll unleash guerrilla warfare in Parliament to block the Brexit deal unless Boris Johnson goes back to Brussels and addresses their concerns with the party said to be looking at multiple options this week. (Twitter/Daily Telegraph)

EU leaders held a brief meeting on Sunday regarding the Brexit in which they said they will play for time rather than rush to decide on PM Johnson’s “extension request”, while other reports suggested the EU is poised to grant the extension in which diplomatic sources stated the UK could leave sooner if the deal is ratified prior to the end of the extension. (Newswires/Sunday Times) France’s European Affairs Minister Amelie de Montchalin urged UK MPs to deliver a "yes or no" verdict so that EU leaders can gather to discuss whether to grant a delay. (Telegraph) German Foreign Minister says a short technical Brexit extension would not be ruled out. (Newswires)

Incoming ECB Chief Lagarde said everybody will be a little bit less well-off due to Brexit and that US-China trade war will certainly give a big haircut to the global economy. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are modestly firmer after risk sentiment turned more constructive following AsiaPac indecisiveness, during which the latest developments (or lack thereof) on the Brexit front and the PBoC’s decision not to cut Loan Prime Rates contributed to the cautious tone. The FTSE 100 (+0.1%) lags amid a stronger Pound on hopes that the worst possible Brexit outcomes are off the table and that PM Johnson may have enough backing for his Brexit deal. Sectors are mostly in the green, apart from defensives, with Consumer Staples (-0.6%), Health Care (-0.5%) and Utilities (-0.2%) all lagging on improved risk appetite. In terms of individual movers; Wirecard (+8.2%) shares spiked higher on the news that the Co. had decided to commission an independent audit relating to the recent allegations made by the FT. Smith and Nephew (-8.0%) sunk after the Co.’s CEO stepped down. Micro Focus (-5.6%) fell on after Open Text confirmed that it is not considering a potential acquisition. Meanwhile, strong earnings saw SAP (+1.7%) move higher, while weak earnings saw Just Eat (-6.5%) head lower. Prudential (-8.2%) shares took a dive on the news that the Co. is to split its UK business (M&G Business) from its Asia operations today. Finally, Osram (-0.4%) shares were initially supported by an upgrade to buy at Commerzbank and after AMS (+4.9%) confirmed its offer for the Co. whilst lowering its minimum accepted threshold, whilst Pearsons (+0.1%) was upgraded to hold from sell at Deutsche Bank.

Microsoft (MSFT) - Prelim results of EU investigations into Co's contracts with EU institutions reveal serious concerns over compliance with data protection rules. (Newswires)

FX

GBP - Sterling has staged a strong comeback from post-super Saturday lows amidst increasingly bullish calls for the Pound and more bouts of short covering on the premise that the risk of a hard Brexit is declining with every move by UK Parliament to assume control of proceedings and/or force another Article 50 extension. Cable snuffed out stops around 1.3000 after eclipsing last week’s 1.2990 peak, but topped out around 1.3012 and Eur/Gbp retreated through 0.8600, though the cross held above last Thursday’s 0.8575 base as the single currency climbed alongside its UK counterpart.

NZD/AUD - Although Sterling’s resilience awaiting PM Johnson’s next move and attempt to put his WA to the HoC is noteworthy, the Antipodean Dollars are outperforming and extending their recovery gains vs the Greenback as the Kiwi climbs above 0.6400 and Aussie nudged over 0.6875. The improvement in US-China trade relations and less dovish on balance near term RBNZ and RBA policy outlooks have underpinned the Nzd and Aud, while the YUAN is also maintaining momentum with the aid of steady PBoC mid-point fixes.

CAD/EUR/CHF/JPY - The Loonie is benefiting from broad Buck weakness, as Usd/Cad eyes 1.3100 and support residing just ahead of the big figure, while the DXY has declined through 97.280 Fib support to fresh sub-97.200 lows and closer to the next downside chart target before 97.000 even (97.033 lows from August). Not much sign of Canadian election jitters or pressure via the ongoing retracement in crude prices, with Tuesday’s retail sales data expected to reveal stronger consumption. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd has been tracking Cable as noted above, but also buoyed by higher Eurozone debt yields on its way up towards 1.1180 and conscious of decent layered option expiry interest from 1.1120-30 (1 bn) through 1.1150-60 (1 bn) to 1.1200 (1.1 bn), while the 200 DMA is also in close proximity (1.1209). Conversely, the Franc and Yen are lagging on mild risk-on trade and safe-haven unwinding, as Usd/Jpy and Usd/Chf pivot 108.50 and 0.9850 respectively after weaker than forecast Japanese trade data overnight and a decline in weekly Swiss sight deposits.

NOK/SEK/TRY - The Scandi Crowns are both clawing back losses amidst the aforementioned risk positive tone, and also consolidating ahead of Thursday’s Riksbank and Norges Bank meetings that preface the ECB convene and could see the former retain guidance for tightening around the turn of the year. Eur/Nok has retreated from new record highs around 10.2440 to sub-10.1900 and Eur/Sek has pulled back further from peaks over 10.9300 to just under 10.7300 at one stage. However, geopolitical jitters have resurfaced to blight Turkey’s Lira after initial relief in wake of the 5-day ceasefire in Syria, with Usd/Try back above 5.8200 in advance of this week’s CBRT rate decision (also on Thursday and contributing to a Central Bank fest) and weighing up whether 1-week repo will be cut again, and if so by how much.

Switzerland conducted its federal election over the weekend in which the anti-immigrant right-wing Swiss People’s Party is set to remain the biggest party with 25.6% of the votes, while the Green Party made historic gains with 13.2% of the votes which saw them overtake the Christian Democrats and become the 4th strongest party. (Guardian/Irish Times) 

FIXED INCOME

Bunds got to within 5 ticks of last week’s lows at 170.78 vs 170.73 before paring some losses and perhaps taking note of the latest Buba monthly report conceding that Q3 GDP could well be contractionary as deteriorating German exports permeate the domestic side of the economy. However, the ensuing bounce has been relatively mild and the 10 year bond remains under 171.00 unlike Gilts that have reclaimed 131.00+ status after picking up underlying bids just shy of the 131.00 handle and some distance from last Thursday’s 130.80 contract base. Meanwhile, US Treasuries remain depressed but off worst levels and the curve is still steeper in to a barren Monday agenda (Fed’s Bowman slated, but into the pre-FOMC blackout period and the event not really suited to anything on policy or the economy in any case).

COMMODITIES                                      

Crude markets are lower, but choppy, after risk sentiment seemingly took a turn for the better in early trade, although some downside was seen later in the session with no immediate fundamental catalysts of note. The recent downside took WTI Dec’ 19 futures back below the 54/bbl mark whilst its Brent counterpart lost the 59/bbl handle after initially consolidating around USD 59.50/bbl region during APAC/early EU trade. In terms of supply news, media reports alleged that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are expected to sign an agreement within 45 days which would see oil production resumed at the neutral zone; and see production at the jointly run fields of Khafji and Wafra reopen following four years of closure amid an ongoing dispute between the two countries. Around 500mln BPD could be brought back online, however, ING note that given that both Iraq and Kuwait are part of the OPEC+ production cut deal, it should not have an impact on overall oil supply for the time being. On the geopolitical front, US Defence Secretary Esper noted that US troops in Syria are with SDF to deny access of oilfields to ISIS and others, but no decision has yet been made about keeping the troops there. Moving on to metals; Gold is slightly lower, but sits well within recent ranges, after the precious metal failed an early bid to get substantially above its 10DMA at 1493/oz. Copper, meanwhile, remains a beneficiary of the mostly weaker buck, despite a lack of decisive PBoC action overnight.

China Iron and Steel Association said iron ore oversupply trend will dominate and prices will keep declining amid increase in imported iron ore and steel scrap supply. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said he spoke to Turkish President Erdogan who very much wants the ceasefire or pause to work and so do the Kurds, while he later commented that the US is in a very powerful position to put sanctions on Turkey and other nations if needed. US President Trump was reportedly mulling leaving a small number of US troops in Syria. (Newswires/WSJ)

US Defense Secretary Esper travelled to Afghanistan on Sunday to help get talks with the Taliban back on track. (Newswires)

NK Vice Defence Minister Ryong said North Korea has exerted endless efforts to build lasting peace and that the US has anachronistic policy against US, adding those that pursue hostile policy will bring about serious consequences. (Newswires)

subject: Halliburton Co (HAL) Q3 19 (USD): diluted EPS 0.34 (exp. 0.34), Revenue 5.55bln (exp. 5.82bln)
content:

  • Remains confident it will achieve high-single digit international growth for FY 2019

ANALYSIS: PBoC surprises by holding Loan Prime Rates steady
content: The PBoC surprised markets by holding its 1yr and 5yr Loan Prime Rates steady at 4.20% (exp. 4.15%) and 4.85% (exp. 4.83%) respectively. Some desks may see this as proof that the central bank is reluctant to allow further indications toward broader easing, despite China's growth slowing to the weakest in 27 years. The question now, says ING, is whether China believes it's unnecessary to reduce interest rates given better than expected September data, or whether it wants to keep the interest rate cut 'bullet' for the future in case trade tensions escalate further. Regardless, ING still expect the PBoC to cut its RRR rate in Q4, even if there is a "phase one deal" released in November. “The Chinese economy has suffered from a long trade war (since March 2018), and the cumulative damage has been increasingly obvious when you look at the data”, says the bank, citing the Y/Y decline in September smartphone production as one piece of evidence. An RRR cut is therefore expected to put downward pressure on interest rates, concludes the bank, adding that this will help both the public sector to finance infrastructure projects and the private sector to reduce interest costs.

content: UK bonds have resumed Liffe on the backfoot after a semi Super Saturday saw England see off Australia comfortably in the RWC, but PM Johnson thwarted by MPs that blocked his bid to table the draft Brexit treaty by voting in favour of the Letwin amendment instead. The 10 year benchmark has been ½ point adrift at 131.25 with some market observers noting stops on a break of 131.40 and prices breached 131.50 prior to that, but faring a tad better than Bunds that have now lost grip of the 171.00 handle. Back to Liffe, the 3 month strip is 1.5-2.5 ticks below parity and just a fraction off lows following a firm start to Monday’s session, with the Dec20 contract 2 ticks ahead at one stage.

subject: Bunds: bears back in the driving seat
content: The 10 year German debt future continues to drift after a modest opening markdown and failure to build on Friday’s recovery momentum, but volumes are relatively light at the start of a potentially bid week as Brexit remains up in the air and the ECB meets on Thursday for President Draghi’s swansong. In truth his final appearance could well be more routine than radical given the multi-pronged policy measures unveiled last month, and the distinct impression if not express guidance that the GC feels it has now done as much as it feels necessary. Bunds are holding just above 171.00 within a 171.01-46 range vs last Friday’s 171.49 close with the Bundesbank monthly bulletin to come before comments from ECB’s de Guindos.

21st October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a cautious tone following last Friday’s lacklustre close on Wall St and amid continued Brexit uncertainty after MPs forced a delay of the vote on UK PM Johnson’s Brexit deal. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were mixed with Australia dragged by underperformance in the tech sector as WiseTech Global shares slumped on return from its trading halt with investors spooked by a recent short seller report that alleged the Co. is overstating profits. However, resilience in the property and mining sectors has limited the losses in Sydney, while Tokyo sentiment was kept afloat by mild JPY weakness as a larger than expected contraction in exports data added to the pressure for the BoJ to act. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) conformed to the indecision after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations but refrained from anticipated cuts to its Loan Prime Rates, with Hong Kong also mildly underpinned after China revised rules to permit mainland investors to trade Hong Kong-listed dual class shares through the Stock Connect.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 21st October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week with a cautious tone following last Friday’s lacklustre close on Wall St and amid continued Brexit uncertainty
  • Parliament vote on the Brexit deal was postponed on Saturday after lawmakers voted (322-306) in favour of passing the Letwin amendment
  • PM Johnson stated that legislation will be tabled in the upcoming week and sent a letter to the EU requesting a Brexit extension which he did not sign
  • Looking ahead highlights include, German PPI, BoE’s Haldane, Fed’s Bowman, ECB VP de Guindos, Canadian Elections

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with a cautious tone following last Friday’s lacklustre close on Wall St and amid continued Brexit uncertainty. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were mixed with Australia dragged by underperformance in the tech sector. However, resilience in the property and mining sectors has limited the losses in Sydney, while Tokyo sentiment was kept afloat by mild JPY weakness as a larger than expected contraction in exports ata added to the pressure for the BoJ to act. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) conformed to the indecision after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations but refrained from anticipated cuts to its Loan Prime Rates, with Hong Kong also mildly underpinned after China revised rules to permit mainland investors to trade Hong Kong-listed dual class shares through the Stock Connect. Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower in which prices retested prior support around the 154.00 level and with demand subdued as Japanese stocks remained afloat, although downside was stemmed amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.16tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0680 vs. Exp. 7.0681 (Prev. 7.0690)

PBoC 1yr Loan Prime Rate 4.20% vs. Exp. 4.15% (Prev. 4.20%). (Newswires) PBoC 5yr Loan Prime Rate 4.85% vs. Exp. 4.83% (Prev. 4.85%)

Chinese House Prices (Sep) Y/Y 8.4% (Prev. 8.8%). (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY)(Sep) -123.0B vs. Exp. 54.0B (Prev. -143.5B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Sep) Y/Y -5.2% vs. Exp. -4.0% (Prev. -8.2%) Japanese Imports (Sep) Y/Y -1.5% vs. Exp. -2.8% (Prev. -11.9%)

UK/EU

Parliament vote on the Brexit deal was postponed on Saturday after lawmakers voted (322-306) in favour of passing the Letwin amendment which withholds approval of the Brexit deal until legislation to ratify it is passed and which effectively forced PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension to January 31st under the Benn Act. Following this, PM Johnson stated that the legislation will be tabled in the upcoming week and sent a letter to the EU requesting a Brexit extension which he did not sign, while he sent 2 other letters where he stated that the extension request was from Parliament and urged the EU not to grant the extension. (Newswires) UK PM Johnson could be held in contempt by Scottish Court for urging EU leaders to ignore a letter asking for an extension to Brexit. Scotland's most senior judge, Carloway, alongside two other judges will hear the allegations today. (Guardian) UK de facto Deputy Gove has triggered official contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit in an attempt to pressure MPs into backing PM Johnson's Brexit deal. (Guardian) Elsewhere, the UK Government are reportedly drawing up plans for an election as soon as November 28th. (Telegraph)

UK Foreign Secretary Raab suggested that the government has the numbers to pass the deal in Commons and is confident the UK will leave on October 31st. Cabinet Minister Gove also stated that the UK will still leave on October 31st and that Parliament cannot change the government’s policy or determination, while there were separate comments from MPs Amber Rudd and Sir Oliver Letwin that suggested they will back PM Johnson’s Brexit deal. (Newswires)

Daily Telegraph’s Political Correspondent Yorke tweeted that a senior DUP figure said the party could back a customs union amendment to the WAB in order to ensure whole of the UK leaves EU under the same customs arrangements and that the party will discuss issue over next 24-48 hours, while he added that another DUP figure said they’ll unleash guerrilla warfare in Parliament to block the Brexit deal unless Boris Johnson goes back to Brussels and addresses their concerns with the party said to be looking at multiple options this week. (Twitter/Daily Telegraph)

EU leaders held a brief meeting on Sunday regarding the Brexit in which they said they will play for time rather than rush to decide on PM Johnson’s “extension request”, while other reports suggested the EU is poised to grant the extension in which diplomatic sources stated the UK could leave sooner if the deal is ratified prior to the end of the extension. (Newswires/Sunday Times) France’s European Affairs Minister Amelie de Montchalin urged UK MPs to deliver a "yes or no" verdict so that EU leaders can gather to discuss whether to grant a delay. (Telegraph)

BoE Governor Carney sees many different monetary policy paths post-Brexit, while he responded that he will not be pre-committing and cited lingering global trade concerns when asked about the potential for post-Brexit hikes. (Newswires)

ECB’s Holzmann (Hawk) said ECB should lower its inflation target in the upcoming review, would support a target of 1.5% or even lower, while he sees indications that EZ economic improvement is on its way and that an orderly Brexit would help. (Newswires)

Incoming ECB Chief Lagarde said everybody will be a little bit less well-off due to Brexit and that US-China trade war will certainly give a big haircut to the global economy. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed UK sovereign rating at AA; Outlook maintained at Watch Negative. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Oct) M/M 0.6% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Oct) Y/Y -0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)

FX 

The greenback is relatively stable with minimal gains seen amid weakness in its transatlantic counterparts in which EUR/USD was pressured near 1.1150 and GBP/USD briefly gave back the 1.2900 handle after ‘Super Saturday’ failed to live up to the hype and the Brexit deal vote was postponed as lawmakers passed the Letwin amendment. This effectively withheld approval of the Brexit deal and therefore forced PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension to January 31st. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses mirrored the mixed trade in their base currencies with gradual pressure observed in Japan’s currency following a 10th consecutive contraction of its exports, while antipodeans shrugged off early downside after a relatively stable CNY reference rate and with NZD/USD the outperformer as it eyed the 0.6400 handle to the upside.

Switzerland conducted its federal election over the weekend in which the anti-immigrant right-wing Swiss People’s Party is set to remain the biggest party with 25.6% of the votes, while the Green Party made historic gains with 13.2% of the votes which saw them overtake the Christian Democrats and become the 4th strongest party. (Guardian/Irish Times) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful amid the indecisive risk tone brought about by continued Brexit uncertainty which saw WTI crude futures stuck to within a tight range as the USD 53.50/bbl level provided a base for prices. Elsewhere, gold was also kept flat by a non-committal risk tone as well as a stable greenback, while copper somewhat outperformed and marginally extended on recent gains with prices hovering around 1-month highs.

 

Baker Hughes Rig Count: oil rigs +1 at 713, Nat-gas rigs -6 at 137, Total US rigs -5 at 851. (Newswires)

 

China Iron and Steel Association said iron ore oversupply trend will dominate and prices will keep declining amid increase in imported iron ore and steel scrap supply. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said he spoke to Turkish President Erdogan who very much wants the ceasefire or pause to work and so do the Kurds, while he later commented that the US is in a very powerful position to put sanctions on Turkey and other nations if needed. US President Trump was reportedly mulling leaving a small number of US troops in Syria. (Newswires/WSJ)

US Defense Secretary Esper travelled to Afghanistan on Sunday to help get talks with the Taliban back on track. (Newswires)

 

NK Vice Defence Minister Ryong said North Korea has exerted endless efforts to build lasting peace and that the US has anachronistic policy against US, adding those that pursue hostile policy will bring about serious consequences. (Newswires) 

US

The Treasury curve bull-steepened on Friday, with yields falling across the curve after softer than expected China GDP, while equity downside also contributed to the upside. Remarks from Fed officials did not deliver any explicit signal ahead of the blackout period, though none leaned too heavily on market pricing, which is pricing a 25bps rate cut with a very high degree of certainty; and this is in keeping with recent commentary (Evans sees no further cuts this year, Kaplan is agnostic, Williams is yet to decide, Powell last week said he was taking it meeting-by-meeting, and Clarida today provided two-way arguments); amid Clarida’s remarks, the TPLEX was stable though equities came under pressure. US T-notes (Z9) settled 4 ticks higher at 130-01.

Fed’s Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said policy is not a pre-set course and decisions will be made "meeting by meeting", while he added the US economy in good place with no evidence of strong labour market putting pressure on inflation. However, Clarida also noted that growth in H2 will be slower than H1, that global manufacturing is slipping and that they have seen a downshift in overall growth relative to the July meeting. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s allies are reportedly compiling a list of potential candidates to replace Acting White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney. (Newswires)

Asia equity markets begin the week with a cautious tone following last Friday’s lacklustre close on Wall St and amid continued Brexit uncertainty after MPs forced a delay of the vote on UK PM Johnson’s Brexit deal. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) are mixed with underperformance seen in Australia’s tech sector as WiseTech Global shares slump on return from its trading halt with investors spooked by a recent short seller report which alleged the Co. is overstating profits. However, resilience in the property and mining sectors has limited the losses in Sydney, while Tokyo trade is just about kept afloat by mild JPY weakness as a larger than expected contraction in exports data adds to the pressure for the BoJ to act. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) conform to the indecision and have diverged after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations but refrained from anticipated cuts to its Loan Prime Rates, with Hong Kong mildly underpinned after China revised rules to permit mainland investors to trade Hong Kong-listed dual class shares through the Stock Connect.

In FX markets, the greenback is relatively stable with minimal gains seen amid weakness in its transatlantic counterparts in which EUR/USD was pressured near 1.1150 and GBP/USD briefly gave back the 1.2900 handle after ‘Super Saturday’ failed to live up to the hype and the Brexit deal vote was postponed as lawmakers passed the Letwin amendment. This effectively withheld approval of the Brexit deal and therefore forced PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension to January 31st under the Benn Act, and although the PM obliged as required by law, he refused to sign the letter and sent further correspondence urging the EU not to grant the extension. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses mirror the mixed trade in their base currencies with gradual pressure observed in Japan’s currency following a 10th consecutive contraction of its exports, while antipodeans shrugged off early downside after a relatively stable CNY reference rate and with NZD/USD the outperformer as it eyes the 0.6400 handle to the upside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower in which prices retested prior support around the 154.00 level and with demand also subdued as Japanese stocks remained afloat, although downside is stemmed amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.16tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.
